critical_mistakes_to_avoid.mistake: Using the 'thumbs up' gesture excessively or in inappropriate contexts
critical_mistakes_to_avoid.why_its_wrong: While generally positive, overly enthusiastic thumbs-up can be seen as informal or even rude in formal or solemn situations in Poland.
critical_mistakes_to_avoid.correct_behavior: Use thumbs up sparingly and prefer a polite nod or verbal affirmation especially in formal or unfamiliar settings.

critical_mistakes_to_avoid.mistake: Addressing strangers or acquaintances without using formal titles and last names initially
critical_mistakes_to_avoid.why_its_wrong: Poles place importance on formal address, especially with older people or in business; skipping formal titles too soon can appear disrespectful.
critical_mistakes_to_avoid.correct_behavior: Use 'Pan' (Mr.) or 'Pani' (Mrs./Ms.) followed by last name when first meeting someone; wait for an invitation to use first names or informal speech.

critical_mistakes_to_avoid.mistake: Arriving very late to social or business appointments
critical_mistakes_to_avoid.why_its_wrong: Polish culture values punctuality; being late can be interpreted as a sign of disrespect or unreliability.
critical_mistakes_to_avoid.correct_behavior: Aim to arrive on time or only a few minutes late. If delayed, apologize and inform the host promptly.

critical_mistakes_to_avoid.mistake: Refusing offered food or drink without a polite reason
critical_mistakes_to_avoid.why_its_wrong: Hospitality is highly valued in Poland; refusing offers of food or drink outright can be perceived as rude or ungrateful.
critical_mistakes_to_avoid.correct_behavior: If you cannot eat or drink, politely explain your reason. Otherwise, accept small portions as a sign of respect.

critical_mistakes_to_avoid.mistake: Talking loudly or making exaggerated gestures in public spaces
critical_mistakes_to_avoid.why_its_wrong: Poles generally value restrained public behavior; loud or overly demonstrative conduct may attract negative attention or be seen as rude.
critical_mistakes_to_avoid.correct_behavior: Keep volume moderate and gestures subtle, especially in public transportation, restaurants, and places of worship.

critical_mistakes_to_avoid.mistake: Giving an even number of flowers when presenting flower bouquets
critical_mistakes_to_avoid.why_its_wrong: Even numbers of flowers are associated with funerals and mourning in Poland.
critical_mistakes_to_avoid.correct_behavior: Always give an odd number of flowers unless you are attending a funeral.

critical_mistakes_to_avoid.mistake: Not removing shoes when invited into someone’s home
critical_mistakes_to_avoid.why_its_wrong: Many Polish households consider it impolite to wear outdoor shoes inside the home due to cleanliness and respect.
critical_mistakes_to_avoid.correct_behavior: Remove your shoes at the entrance when invited to a private home; hosts often provide slippers.

critical_mistakes_to_avoid.mistake: Avoiding or dismissing religious customs publicly
critical_mistakes_to_avoid.why_its_wrong: Poland is a predominantly Catholic country with strong religious traditions; disregarding or criticizing religion can offend locals.
critical_mistakes_to_avoid.correct_behavior: Show respect for religious places and customs; behave discreetly in churches and during religious ceremonies.

essential_etiquette.do: Offer a firm handshake with direct eye contact; use formal titles initially
essential_etiquette.dont: Do not hug or kiss on the first meeting unless invited

essential_etiquette.do: Wait for the host to invite you to start eating; say 'Smacznego' (Enjoy your meal)
essential_etiquette.dont: Do not start eating before everyone is served or begin eating with your hands

essential_etiquette.do: Bring small gifts like sweets or flowers (odd number); present gifts with both hands
essential_etiquette.dont: Avoid gifts in even numbers or giving sharp objects (like knives)

essential_etiquette.do: Maintain a calm and respectful demeanor; queue patiently
essential_etiquette.dont: Avoid loud talking, public displays of intoxication, or disorderly conduct

essential_etiquette.do: Speak politely and clearly; use formal language with strangers and elders
essential_etiquette.dont: Do not interrupt or speak too informally without invitation

essential_etiquette.do: Dress modestly when visiting churches; light candles quietly and respectfully
essential_etiquette.dont: Do not take photos in churches without permission or behave irreverently
Avoid excessive nodding or shaking your head too rapidly, which can indicate sarcasm

essential_etiquette.do: Offer seats to elderly or pregnant passengers; valid tickets must be purchased in trams and buses
essential_etiquette.dont: Do not board public transport without valid tickets or push to get on/out

cultural_norms.description: Poles maintain formality in social and professional interactions initially. Titles and polite forms of address are standard until deeper familiarity is established.
Guests are treated with high regard; hosts typically offer food or drinks and expect polite acceptance as a sign of mutual respect.
Time is treated seriously, especially for meetings and appointments. Being even a few minutes late may be viewed negatively.
Catholicism deeply influences customs, holidays, and social values. Religious holidays and church attendance remain integral to community life.
Poles may initially appear reserved or modest in emotional expression, particularly with strangers; openness increases with trust.

key_traditions.context: December 24th, family dinner with specific customs like breaking and sharing opłatek (wafer)
key_traditions.visitor_expectations: If invited, participate respectfully by joining in the sharing of opłatek and trying traditional dishes.

key_traditions.context: November 1st, visiting cemeteries to honor deceased relatives with candles and flowers
key_traditions.visitor_expectations: Observe solemnity and silence at cemeteries; refrain from loud behavior during this important day.

key_traditions.context: Celebrated similarly or even more than birthdays, occurring on the saint’s day associated with a person’s given name
key_traditions.visitor_expectations: Congratulating friends or colleagues on their name day is appreciated; small gifts or cards may be appropriate.

key_traditions.context: Easter Monday tradition involving water fights, especially among youth
key_traditions.visitor_expectations: If partaking, join good-naturedly; if avoiding, politely excuse to not offend locals.

key_traditions.context: Performed during festivals and national holidays, representing regional heritage
key_traditions.visitor_expectations: Show respect by watching attentively and applauding; asking before photographing performers is polite.

common_misconceptions: Poland is the same as Russia or another Slavic country; in fact, Poland has a distinct language, culture, and history.
Polish people are always formal and unfriendly; many are warm, hospitable, and open once trust is established.
Poland is uniformly traditional; urban areas and younger generations embrace modern lifestyles and global culture.
Everyone in Poland speaks Russian; in reality, English and German are more commonly learned as foreign languages now.
Poland is only about vodka and pierogi; Polish cuisine and culture are diverse and sophisticated beyond stereotypes.
